DOCNAME: CASE OF LAUKKANEN AND MANNINEN v. FINLAND
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in Riihimäki and PERSON , respectively .

CARDINAL . The applicants were charged before ORG ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätt ) of PERSON ; the first applicant with unauthorised use of a motor vehicle and driving without a licence and the second applicant with unauthorised use of a motor vehicle , among other offences . The applicants were represented before ORG by legal counsel .

CARDINAL . At the hearing before ORG , on DATE , the public prosecutor called an eyewitness , ORG , a police officer . He had recognised the applicants and had seen them enter a car that was later reported stolen . When the witness gave evidence it appeared that there might have been other police officers in the area . The witness refused to answer some questions about his whereabouts when observing the applicants and also declined to confirm whether there had been other officers in the area , since he had been assigned to another operation not related to the applicants’ actions . The witness testified that he had recognised the applicants since he had met them before during pre - trial investigations . He had seen the first applicant enter the car by opening the door from the driver ’s side . The second applicant had arrived DATE and had entered the car , and the car had left . The witness had seen its registration plate and remembered that it had contained the same digit CARDINAL times .

CARDINAL . The applicants denied the charges against them , explaining they did not know anything about the incident they were accused of . They also stated to ORG that they wished to be informed of the identity of the police officers witness ORG had mentioned in order to be able to call them as witnesses .

CARDINAL . ORG convicted the applicants on DATE of unauthorised use of a motor vehicle , among other offences , and sentenced the first applicant to CARDINAL days’ and the second applicant to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment . In so far as the judgment concerned the offences referred to above , the court based itself on the testimony of the eyewitness . There was no other evidence .

CARDINAL . The applicants appealed to ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätt ) of PERSON , arguing that they should not have been convicted on the basis of the testimony of CARDINAL eyewitness , since it would have been possible to hear the police officers who had been in the area at the same time . The applicants demanded a chance to hear those police officers as witnesses , requesting an oral hearing to be held before ORG or that the case be referred back to ORG for a re - hearing . They stressed that the names of those police officers had not been known until the public prosecutor gave his answer to the applicants’ appeal to ORG . After the hearing at ORG the public prosecutor had established that the QUANTITY police officers had been in the area but had not observed the incident .

CARDINAL . NORP The public prosecutor submitted his observations on the applicants’ appeal to ORG on DATE . In his observations he revealed the identity of the proposed witnesses in question . He objected to the hearing of those witnesses and to the ORG request to refer the case back to ORG . He stated that he had , on DATE , discussed the case with both officers who had told him that they had seen the applicants in the area but had not made any observations concerning the unauthorised use of the vehicle . The public prosecutor stated that the applicants had been able to question witness ORG , whereas the CARDINAL other officers could not be considered as witnesses who would give evidence on the applicants’ behalf within the meaning of LAW ( d ) of the LAW .

CARDINAL . The applicants were provided with an opportunity to submit written comments on the prosecutor ’s observations . The first applicant asserted , inter alia , that he must be afforded a right to obtain answers from ORG to the questions he had put to him , and a right to hear the above - mentioned CARDINAL police officers as witnesses . The second applicant argued that the public prosecutor ’s statement about his conversations with the police officers in question was not comparable to their being heard as witnesses before a court . He noted that the applicants could have had other questions put to them than those put by the prosecutor .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld ORG judgment , rejecting the applicants’ request for an oral hearing and the request to refer the case back to ORG . It found , in accordance with LAW ( LAW , section DATE , subsection CARDINAL ) , that the applicants had failed to state what they intended to prove by the witness evidence proposed . It also recalled , according to LAW , section CARDINAL ) , that a court must not allow irrelevant evidence to be presented . ORG also rejected the request to hear PERSON again as , in its view , additional questions would not bring any further clarification to the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG refused the applicants leave to appeal .

CARDINAL . According to LAW , Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) , of LAW ( oikeudenkäymiskaari , rättegångsbalken ) as in force at the relevant time , in his appeal to a ORG an appellant must identify the evidence to be relied on and the facts to be proved by that evidence . According to LAW , LAW , of that same LAW , a court must not allow irrelevant evidence to be presented .
CARDINAL . According to LAW , LAW , of LAW , the parties must obtain the necessary evidence . A court may also , when considered necessary , decide to obtain evidence on its own initiative .

CARDINAL . According to LAW of LAW ( poliisilaki , polislagen ) , a member of the police force , when heard as a witness or otherwise , is not under an obligation to disclose “ tactical or technical matters ” which are covered by secrecy .

CARDINAL . According to the reservation made by GPE in accordance with LAW , as in force at the relevant time , GPE could not guarantee a right to an oral hearing in so far as the NORP laws at the time of the events at issue did not provide such a right . This applied , inter alia , to proceedings before ORG in accordance with LAW .
